+package de.metas.serviceprovider.milestone;
+
+import de.metas.organization.OrgId;
+import lombok.Builder;
+import lombok.Data;
+import lombok.NonNull;
+
+import javax.annotation.Nullable;
+import java.time.LocalDateTime;
+
+@Data
+@Builder
+public class Milestone
+{
+	@NonNull
+	private OrgId orgId;
+
+	@Nullable
+	private MilestoneId milestoneId;
+
+	@Nullable
+	private String externalId;
+
+	@Nullable
+	private String description;
+
+	@NonNull
+	private String name;
+
+	@NonNull
+	private String value;
+
+	@Nullable
+	private LocalDateTime dueDate;

replies.bodyText: no exact reason, LocalDateTime was enough for what I needed.
replies.author: pvpurcarcosmin

replies.bodyText:
IMHO dueDate is a logistic date,  so it has to be precise, so timezone is needed for that.
LocalDateTime is a date+time but without a time zone.
If for example, the due date is "2020-04-20 13:14" it's important to know in which timezone, CEST, EEST?
If time is not important, I would suggest using LocalDate.
replies.author: teosarca

replies.bodyText: I see, since time is not set for dueDate, I'll go with LocalDate, thx.
replies.author: pvpurcarcosmin

@teosarca if you see this, we are aware of the n+1 problem, but chose not to talked it this time. if mass-import (which happens very rarely) becomes too slow, we can still put a staging service in between.
